Expectation1: Deliver packages on time and to the correct address
Situation1: A package arrives slightly later than expected, but still within the same day
Expectation2: Arrive at the polling station during designated voting hours
Situation2: Late-afternoon errands leave just a couple of hours before the polls close.
Story:
I glanced at the clock on my dashboard as I pulled up to the depot. The last package of the day had just arrived—late, but still technically on time. My supervisor’s words echoed in my mind: “Every delivery, on time, no exceptions.” I loaded the box into my van, checking the address. It was across town, and traffic was already thickening. 

But today wasn’t just any day. It was election day, and I’d promised myself I’d vote. The polling station closed in two hours, and I still had a handful of deliveries left, this last one being the farthest. My phone buzzed with a reminder: “Don’t forget to vote!” I felt a knot tighten in my stomach. If I delivered the package first, I might miss my chance to vote. If I voted first, the package could be late, and I’d risk a complaint or worse. 

Both roles demanded my presence, my responsibility. I could almost hear the disappointment in my supervisor’s voice, and at the same time, I imagined the regret of not casting my ballot. I sat in the van, keys in hand, torn between duty and civic responsibility, unsure which road to take.
